canonical_explanation.text: Mathematical reasoning involves analyzing statements and their logical structure. A statement (proposition) is a sentence that is either true or false, but not both. Compound statements are formed using connectives: 'and' (conjunction), 'or' (disjunction), 'if-then' (conditional/implication), 'if and only if' (biconditional). The negation of a statement p is 'not p'. The converse of 'if p then q' is 'if q then p'. The contrapositive is 'if not q then not p'. Quantifiers include 'for all' (∀) and 'there exists' (∃).
rules: Negation: ~p is true when p is false and vice versa
Conjunction (p ∧ q): true only when both p and q are true
Disjunction (p ∨ q): true when at least one is true
Conditional (p → q): false only when p is true and q is false
Contrapositive of (p → q) is (~q → ~p) — logically equivalent

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a mathematical statement?
questions.explanation_correct: '2 + 3 = 5' is a declarative sentence that is either true or false (it's true). Commands, exclamations, and questions are not statements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A statement must be a declarative sentence that can be assigned a truth value. Only '2 + 3 = 5' qualifies.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'All triangles are equilateral' is:
questions.explanation_correct: The negation of 'All A are B' is 'There exists an A that is not B', i.e., 'Some triangles are not equilateral'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negation of ∀x P(x) is ∃x ~P(x). 'Some triangles are not equilateral' is correct.

questions.question_text: The compound statement 'p and q' is true when:

options.text: Both p and q are true
Either p or q is true
p is true and q is false
Neither p nor q is true

questions.explanation_correct: A conjunction (p ∧ q) is true only when both components are true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 'and' connective requires both parts to be true.

questions.question_text: 'x + 5 = 7' is a mathematical statement.
questions.explanation_correct: 'x + 5 = 7' is not a statement because its truth value depends on x. It's an open sentence. It becomes a statement only when x is assigned a specific value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open sentence with a variable is not a statement until the variable is given a value.

questions.question_text: The negation of '√2 is irrational' is:
questions.explanation_correct: The negation of '√2 is irrational' is '√2 is not irrational' which is the same as '√2 is rational'. Both A and B are equivalent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Not irrational' means 'rational'. Both express the same negation.

questions.question_text: The compound statement 'p or q' is false when:

options.text: Both p and q are true
p is true, q is false
Both p and q are false
p is false, q is true

questions.explanation_correct: A disjunction (p ∨ q) is false only when both p and q are false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'Or' is false only when both components are false.

questions.question_text: The converse of 'If a number is divisible by 10, then it is divisible by 5' is:

options.text: If a number is divisible by 5, then it is divisible by 10
If a number is not divisible by 10, then it is not divisible by 5
If a number is not divisible by 5, then it is not divisible by 10
A number is divisible by 10 if and only if it is divisible by 5

questions.explanation_correct: The converse of 'if p then q' is 'if q then p'. So: 'If divisible by 5, then divisible by 10'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Converse swaps hypothesis and conclusion. Note: the converse is false (e.g., 15 is divisible by 5 but not 10).

questions.question_text: The contrapositive of 'If it rains, then the ground is wet' is:

options.text: If the ground is wet, then it rains
If it does not rain, then the ground is not wet
If the ground is not wet, then it does not rain
It rains if and only if the ground is wet

questions.explanation_correct: Contrapositive of 'if p then q' is 'if not q then not p'. So: 'If the ground is not wet, then it does not rain'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Contrapositive: negate both and swap. ~q → ~p.

questions.question_text: Identify the connective in: 'A number is even if and only if it is divisible by 2'.
questions.explanation_correct: 'If and only if' (biconditional) connects the two parts. It means both the conditional and its converse are true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'If and only if' is the biconditional connective (p ↔ q).

questions.question_text: Which statement is logically equivalent to 'if p then q'?

options.text: If not p then not q
If not q then not p
p if and only if q

questions.explanation_correct: The contrapositive 'if not q then not p' is logically equivalent to 'if p then q'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A conditional is equivalent to its contrapositive. Option A is the converse, B is the inverse.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'There exists a real number x such that x² < 0' is:

options.text: There exists a real x such that x² ≥ 0
There exists x such that x² = 0

questions.explanation_correct: Negation of ∃x P(x) is ∀x ~P(x). So: 'For all real x, x² ≥ 0'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negating an existential quantifier gives a universal quantifier with the negated predicate.

questions.question_text: The inverse of 'if p then q' is ___.
questions.correct_answer: if not p then not q
questions.explanation_correct: The inverse negates both the hypothesis and conclusion: ~p → ~q.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Inverse of p → q is ~p → ~q.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'p and q' is:
questions.explanation_correct: By De Morgan's law: ~(p ∧ q) = (~p) ∨ (~q).
questions.explanation_incorrect: De Morgan: negation of 'and' becomes 'or' with negated parts.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'p or q' is:
questions.explanation_correct: By De Morgan's law: ~(p ∨ q) = (~p) ∧ (~q).
questions.explanation_incorrect: De Morgan: negation of 'or' becomes 'and' with negated parts.

questions.question_text: Consider 'If n is a prime greater than 2, then n is odd'. Which method validates this?
questions.explanation_correct: Direct proof: If n > 2 is prime, it can't be even (since even numbers > 2 are divisible by 2, not prime). By contradiction: assume n > 2 is prime and even, then 2|n, contradicting primality. Both methods work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both direct proof and contradiction can validate this statement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a compound statement?

options.text: The sun rises in the east
New Delhi is the capital of India

questions.explanation_correct: '2 is even and 3 is odd' combines two statements using the connective 'and'. The others are simple statements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compound statement uses a logical connective (and, or, if-then, etc.) to combine statements.

questions.question_text: The statement 'If x² = 25, then x = 5' is disproved by the counterexample:
questions.explanation_correct: x = −5 gives x² = 25 but x ≠ 5. This is a counterexample since p is true but q is false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: (−5)² = 25 but −5 ≠ 5, disproving the conditional.

questions.question_text: The quantifier in 'For every natural number n, n + 1 > n' is:
questions.explanation_correct: 'For every' is the universal quantifier ∀.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'For every' = 'For all' = ∀.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'For all x, x² > 0' is:

options.text: There exists x such that x² ≤ 0
There exists x such that x² > 0

questions.explanation_incorrect: Negating ∀ gives ∃ with the negated predicate.

questions.question_text: A conditional statement and its contrapositive are logically equivalent.
questions.explanation_correct: p → q ≡ ~q → ~p. They always have the same truth value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The contrapositive is always logically equivalent to the original conditional.

questions.question_text: The component statements of '3 is odd and 4 is even' are:

options.text: p: 3 is odd, q: 4 is even
p: 3 is a number, q: 4 is a number
p: 3 and 4, q: odd and even

questions.explanation_correct: The conjunction 'and' combines p: '3 is odd' and q: '4 is even'. Both are independent statements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Split at the connective 'and': p = '3 is odd', q = '4 is even'.

questions.question_text: The contrapositive of 'If a quadrilateral is a square, then it is a rectangle' is:

options.text: If a quadrilateral is a rectangle, then it is a square
If a quadrilateral is not a rectangle, then it is not a square
If a quadrilateral is not a square, then it is not a rectangle
A quadrilateral is a square if and only if it is a rectangle

questions.explanation_correct: Contrapositive of 'if square then rectangle' is 'if not rectangle then not square'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ~q → ~p: 'If not a rectangle, then not a square'.

questions.question_text: Which of these is NOT a statement?
questions.explanation_correct: 'Please sit down' is a command/request, not a declarative sentence. It has no truth value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Commands and requests are not statements. Even false claims like 'earth is flat' are statements.

questions.question_text: The statement 'If p then q' is false only when:

options.text: p is true and q is true
p is true and q is false
p is false and q is true
p is false and q is false

questions.explanation_correct: An implication p → q is false only when the hypothesis is true but the conclusion is false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p → q is false only in the case T → F.

questions.question_text: The negation of the statement 'If I am in Delhi, then I am in India' is:

options.text: If I am not in Delhi, then I am not in India
I am in Delhi and I am not in India
If I am in India, then I am in Delhi
I am not in Delhi or I am in India

questions.explanation_correct: ~(p → q) = p ∧ ~q. So: 'I am in Delhi AND I am not in India'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The negation of p → q is p ∧ ~q (both hypothesis true and conclusion false).

questions.question_text: Prove that '√2 is irrational' — which method is commonly used?
questions.explanation_correct: The irrationality of √2 is classically proved by contradiction: assume √2 = p/q in lowest terms, derive a contradiction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Proof by contradiction (assuming √2 is rational) is the standard approach.

questions.question_text: The 'inclusive or' in 'p or q' means:

options.text: Either p or q, but not both
At least one of p or q is true
Both p and q are true

questions.explanation_correct: In mathematics, 'or' is inclusive: p ∨ q is true when at least one (possibly both) is true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mathematical 'or' includes the case where both are true.

questions.question_text: The converse and inverse of a conditional statement are:
questions.explanation_correct: Converse (q → p) and inverse (~p → ~q) are contrapositives of each other, so they are logically equivalent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The converse q → p and the inverse ~p → ~q are equivalent. Neither need be equivalent to the original.

questions.question_text: 'He is tall' is a mathematical statement.
questions.explanation_correct: 'He is tall' is ambiguous — 'he' is unspecified and 'tall' is subjective. It's not a well-defined mathematical statement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Without a specific referent and a precise criterion, this is not a statement.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'Sum of 2 and 3 is 6' is:
questions.explanation_correct: The negation simply denies the original: 'Sum of 2 and 3 is NOT 6'. We don't specify what it equals instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negation: 'not (2+3=6)' means '2+3 ≠ 6'.

questions.question_text: To disprove a universal statement '∀x, P(x)', it suffices to find:

options.text: One x where P(x) is true
One x where P(x) is false
All x where P(x) is false
A proof that P(x) is always true

questions.explanation_correct: A single counterexample (one x where P(x) fails) is sufficient to disprove a universal statement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One counterexample disproves ∀x P(x).

questions.question_text: In the statement 'If x is a multiple of 6, then x is a multiple of 3', the hypothesis is:
questions.explanation_correct: In 'if p then q', p is the hypothesis. Here p = 'x is a multiple of 6'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hypothesis is the 'if' part: 'x is a multiple of 6'.

questions.question_text: The biconditional 'p if and only if q' is true when:

options.text: Both p and q are true, or both are false
p is true and q is false

questions.explanation_correct: p ↔ q is true when p and q have the same truth value (both true or both false).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The biconditional requires matching truth values.

questions.question_text: A sentence that is either true or false but not both is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A mathematical statement (or proposition) is a declarative sentence with exactly one truth value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is the definition of a statement (proposition).

questions.question_text: The negation of 'Every integer is either even or odd' is:

options.text: No integer is even or odd
Some integer is neither even nor odd
Every integer is neither even nor odd
Some integer is both even and odd

questions.explanation_correct: ~(∀x, x is even or odd) = ∃x, ~(x is even or odd) = ∃x, x is neither even nor odd.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negate the universal and the predicate: ∃x such that x is neither even nor odd.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements can be proved by giving a counterexample?

options.text: Sum of two primes is always even

questions.explanation_correct: A is disproved by 2 (prime but even). B is disproved by 2 + 3 = 5 (odd). Both false universal statements are disproved by counterexample.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Counterexample for A: 2. Counterexample for B: 2+3=5.

questions.question_text: The statement 'p: 5 > 3 AND q: 2 + 2 = 5' is:
questions.explanation_correct: p is true (5 > 3) but q is false (2 + 2 ≠ 5). Since conjunction requires both to be true, p ∧ q is false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p ∧ q is false because q is false.

questions.question_text: The statement 'p: 5 > 3 OR q: 2 + 2 = 5' is:
questions.explanation_correct: p is true. For disjunction, at least one true makes the whole statement true. So p ∨ q is true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: p ∨ q is true because p is true (regardless of q).

questions.question_text: Consider 'If n² is even, then n is even'. The proof by contradiction assumes:

options.text: n² is even and n is even
n² is even and n is odd
n² is odd and n is even
n² is odd and n is odd

questions.explanation_correct: To prove p → q by contradiction, assume p and ~q: 'n² is even and n is odd', then derive a contradiction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Assume the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is false, then find a contradiction.

questions.question_text: A conditional and its converse are logically equivalent.
questions.explanation_correct: p → q and q → p are NOT equivalent. Example: 'If square then rectangle' is true, but the converse is false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The converse is not equivalent. Only the contrapositive is equivalent to the original.

questions.question_text: The component statements of 'Two lines are parallel if and only if they do not intersect' are:

options.text: p: Two lines are parallel, q: They do not intersect
p: Two lines intersect, q: They are parallel

questions.explanation_correct: The biconditional connects p: 'Two lines are parallel' with q: 'They do not intersect'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Split at 'if and only if': p = 'Two lines are parallel', q = 'They do not intersect'.

questions.question_text: Which quantifier is in 'There exists a triangle with all angles equal'?
questions.explanation_correct: 'There exists' is the existential quantifier ∃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 'There exists' = ∃.

questions.question_text: The converse, inverse, and contrapositive of 'If a polygon is a triangle, then it has 3 sides' — which is true?
questions.explanation_correct: The original is true. A polygon has 3 sides iff it's a triangle, so the converse is also true. Since the original and converse are both true, the inverse and contrapositive are also true.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since 'triangle' and '3 sides' are equivalent for polygons, the biconditional holds, making all four forms true.

questions.question_text: The negation of '2 is even and 3 is odd' is:

options.text: 2 is not even and 3 is not odd

questions.explanation_correct: ~(p ∧ q) = ~p ∨ ~q = '2 is not even OR 3 is not odd' = '2 is odd or 3 is even'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: De Morgan's law: negation of 'and' = 'or' of negations.

questions.question_text: To prove 'There exists an even prime number', it suffices to:

options.text: Give one example of an even prime

questions.explanation_correct: An existential statement ∃x P(x) is proved by producing one witness. Example: 2 is an even prime.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One example suffices for an existential proof: 2 is an even prime.

questions.question_text: 'If you study hard, then you will pass the exam' — which is the conclusion?
questions.explanation_correct: In 'if p then q', q is the conclusion. Here q = 'You will pass the exam'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The conclusion is the 'then' part of the conditional.

questions.question_text: The contrapositive of 'if p then q' is ___.
questions.correct_answer: if not q then not p
questions.explanation_correct: Contrapositive: ~q → ~p.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negate both and swap: ~q → ~p.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true?
questions.explanation_correct: In B: '3+4 = 7' is true. For 'or', one true part suffices. B is true. A is false (3+4≠8). C: both false. D: both false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Only B has at least one true component connected by 'or'.

questions.question_text: To validate a statement using the method of contradiction, we assume:

options.text: The negation of the statement is true
The statement is neither true nor false

questions.explanation_correct: In proof by contradiction, we assume the negation of what we want to prove, then derive a logical contradiction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We start by assuming ~p and show this leads to an impossibility.

questions.question_text: The negation of 'If x is a natural number, then x is positive' is:

options.text: x is a natural number and x is not positive
If x is not a natural number, then x is not positive
x is not a natural number or x is positive
If x is positive, then x is a natural number

questions.explanation_correct: ~(p → q) = p ∧ ~q. 'x is a natural number AND x is not positive'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Negation of p → q is p ∧ ~q.
